htmlBanner:
Select

Selects present a list of options from which a user can select one option, or several. A selected option can represent a value in a form, or can be used as an action to filter or sort existing content.

Accessibility_SelectFilter.html:
Overview

Select filter

Select accessibility involves designing dropdown menus that are easy to use and understandable for people with disabilities. Key considerations include providing clear and concise labels, ensuring sufficient contrast, enabling keyboard accessibility, providing focus indicators, offering autocomplete suggestions or search filters, and ensuring clear error messages. By addressing these elements, designers can create dropdown menus that are inclusive and accessible to all users.

Combo box

Combo box accessibility refers to designing combo boxes (also known as dropdown menus) in a way that makes them easy to use and understandable for people with disabilities. Accessibility features may include providing clear and concise labels, ensuring the combo box has enough contrast with the background, and making sure that the combo box is keyboard accessible.

Keyboard Navigation

Select filter

To navigate a Select, use a Tab

Combo Box

To navigate a combo box field, use a Tab

Combo Box

The interactive element before the text field.

When user begins typing, the dropdown menu will appear and filter based on any matches.

or

Use up or down arrow keys to navigate between menu items.

or

Enter or space to commit to selection in dropdown menu. Then automatically close the dropdown menu.

or

Use up or down arrow keys to navigate between menu items.

The next interactive element.

Screen Reader

Selet filter

The Select screen reader must inform a user of at least the following, normally in this order:

Name - visible label OR screen reader text
Current option value
State - required, read-only, disabled, etc.
Menu state - collapsed or opened

Screen readers may not read placeholder text. Screen reader output can vary significantly depending on the userâ€™s web browser and other factors, so to accommodate screen reader users, you should always include a static label.
The following are the announcement orders:

Dropdown Select

Select, selected

Select, dropdown menu opened

Structure Role and Initial status not applicable

Combo box

The combo box field screen reader must inform a user of at least the following, normally in this order:

Name - visible label OR screen reader text
Current option value
State - required, read-only, disabled, etc.
Menu state - collapsed or opened

Screen readers may not read placeholder text. Screen reader output can vary significantly depending on the userâ€™s web browser and other factors, so to accommodate screen reader users, you should always include a static label.

The following are the announcement orders:

Combo box, unselected

Initial status not applicable

Combo box, typed or selected

Initial status not applicable

Combo box, typing

Initial status not applicable

Vertical spacing between text field types

Spacing between each text field type element within a form should be 16px.

Spacing between the Select and dropdown menu should be 8px, even when there is helper text.

Guideline.html:
Anatomy

When to use

Selects can be used in forms on full pages, in modals, or on side panels. The Select component is used to filter or sort contents on a page. It is a stylized version of the select component, and can be styled as needed.

When Not to use

It is best practice not to use a Select if there are two options to choose from. In this case, use a radio button group instead.
Do not nest Selects or use them to display overly complex information. Keep option selections as straight forward as possible.
Consider using a native select if most of your experience is form-based or frequently used on mobile platforms. The native select works more easily with a native form when submitting data and is also easier to use on a mobile platform

Usage

Selects are often used in forms when there are a limited number of options available for a particular field. Selects can help to conserve space on the form, as they only display one option at a time, but allow users to select from a larger set of options.

Selects are commonly used for fields such as country, state/province, gender, and age range, among others.

In general, avoid traditional Selects when there are more than 10 or fewer than 5 options. When there are more than 10 options, consider using a combo box, another variation of the Select, to help users find what they need faster.

Types

There are four different variants of Selects that support various kinds of functionalityâ€”select, multiselect, filter and combo box.

Anatomy

Select

Label text
Required indicator (optional)
Info button (optional)
Supporting text
Helper text (optional)
Dropdown indicator

Multiselect

Filter

Filter icon
Supporting text
Dropdown indicator

Combo Box

Label text
Required indicator
Info button
Supporting text
Helper text
Dropdown indicator

Element and Content Reference

Supporting Text

Placeholder textâ€¨Placeholder text is presented in the Select by default if no selection has been made from the dropdown menu. This is important to have in case the Select does not have a label above it. Use clear placeholder text in the Select so that users understand the purpose. Selected text

Behavior

Dropdown menu selection

A dropdown menu consists of a list of options that appear when the user clicks any part of the Select container.

When the menu is opened, the user can select an option by clicking on a list item. The menu will automatically close and the selected value will appear in the Select.

The user can also scroll through the list of options displayed to see all possible values. This can be done using the mouse or keyboard navigation.

After selection/preselection

Once the user has selected an item in the dropdown menu, either by mouse click or keyboard enter, the menu will automatically close and the selected value will appear in the Select (in place of the placeholder text or previously selected value).

When the user opens the dropdown menu to make another selection, the currently selected value will have a trailing checkmark appear on the list item itself.

Filter selection

A Filter behaves the same as a Select, but in addition to its functionality, it will updated the associated content below (Example: data table) when a value is selected.

Combo Box selection

A Combo Box allows users to make a selection from a predefined list of options and is typically used when there are a large amount of options to choose from.

By default, the combo box displays placeholder text in the field when closed.

The menu opens by clicking anywhere in the field and you can start typing to sort through the list of options. The option that best matches the typed characters is highlighted.

Custom values are not allowed as a valid value in a combo box. If an typed value does not return or match any options, the user should be alerted via an empty state message.

Selecting an option closes the menu and the selected option replaces the placeholder text.

Sizing

There is only one Select height size: 32px.

Content

Labels

Keep labels short. 4-5 words max.
Labels should clearly state the requirement status.
Donâ€™t use a colon (:) at the end of a label for a form field. The component already communicates the relationship between label and input.
Labels should typically be in noun form or a "thing" (like "Name" or "Password). But if a text field needs more of a call to action, it can use a verb construction.
Selects must always include a label. A select without a label is ambiguous and not accessible.

Helper text

Helper text is optional. The same goes for an info button and tooltip.
When used, helper text is always available when the input is focused and appears underneath the field. The exceptions are when an error, warning, or success message replaces the helper text.

Placeholder text

Placeholder text is not required and by default not shown in text fields.
Placeholder text can be harmful to user interactions and should only be added when necessary.

Capitalization

Use sentence case for all main elements (Labels, Helper text, and Placeholder text), except for product names and proper nouns.

Validation

Switch helper text with validation textâ€¨When a Select already has helper text and an error or warning happens, the error or warning text replaces the helper text. Once resolved, the error or warning disappears, and the helper text description reappears below the field. Write validation text that shows a solution

Error message with instructions and context.

Warning message with instruction and context.

Accessibility.html:
Overview

Write some general guidelines around the accessibility of the component. These could be principles for usage, the accessibility goal of the component, or some tips.
Place any pertinent WCAG references here as well.
Example:â€¨â€It is also important to avoid designing alerts that disappear automatically. An alert that disappears too quickly can lead to failure to meet WCAG 2.0 success criterion 2.2.3.â€
Check out W3C for a quick idea on potential WCAG 2.0 references.
Also, check out Control Hubâ€™s Accessibility Specs and leverage any content there.

Select filter

Select accessibility involves designing dropdown menus that are easy to use and understandable for people with disabilities. Key considerations include providing clear and concise labels, ensuring sufficient contrast, enabling keyboard accessibility, providing focus indicators, offering autocomplete suggestions or search filters, and ensuring clear error messages. By addressing these elements, designers can create dropdown menus that are inclusive and accessible to all users.

Keyboard Navigation

To navigate a Select, use a Tab stop to navigate between elements. Keyboard interactions for select/filter fields include:

Element
Purpose

Tab

Moves focus to next interactive element

Shift

+

Tab

Moves focus back to the previous interactive element

Enter

Selects a list item and then closes the dropdown menu

Space

Selects a list item and then closes the dropdown menu

Esc

/

Tab

Closes the dropdown menu without committing to a selection

Up Arrow

Moves the selection within the dropdown menu list items

Home

/

End

Moves the selection to the first or last item in a dropdown menu respectively

Keyboard interactions (Input Chips)

Controls

OR

To move focus to next element.

Screen Reader

Selet filter

The Select screen reader must inform a user of at least the following, normally in this order:

Name - visible label OR screen reader text
Current option value
State - required, read-only, disabled, etc.
Menu state - collapsed or opened

Screen readers may not read placeholder text. Screen reader output can vary significantly depending on the userâ€™s web browser and other factors, so to accommodate screen reader users, you should always include a static label.
The following are the announcement orders:

Dropdown Select

Visible Label
